Input.threadtitle: Normalization (question answered!)
Input.posts:
Hi, Considering the learning material and mean normalization... in Programming exercise we use std function to calculate 'standard deviation', where computation gets another result as when using max - min. Using max - min in Programming exercise 1 (submit no. 4 - Feature normalization) is invalid after submission, however using max-min is needed for Quiz IV Linear reg... question 1. Can anyone enlighten me why do we use std in one example and max - min in another? Thank you
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post

Upvotes:

It kinda intuitive but not straight forward. So we have x * $$\theta$$ = y where x is as given in the lecture and $$\theta$$ is a column vector of all the $$\theta$$s Now since x may or may not be a square matrix, pre-multiply the transpose of x (x') on both sides. x' * x $$\theta$$ = x' * y now we have (x' * x) being a square matrix. Pre-multiply both sides with inv(x' * x) and we get $$\theta$$ = inv(x' * x)* x' * y

Hi there. Just one caveat, if I may. Although $$X^T * X$$ is indeed a square matrix, it might not be invertible (technically, it might be 'singular'). In this case, it is not advisable to use Octave's 'inv'. That is why I recommend that you watch Prof. Ng's videos that cover the theory associated with this exercise. Cheers! -AJ

The prof only talks about singularity and octave and the 'inv' and 'pinv' function because computationally singularity is caused by incorrect assumption of X. pinv just ignores bad mathematical skills of the operator and fixes the matrix. It does not substitute the fact that the matrix becomes non-singular by itself. Hope this makes it more clear.

On Slide 6 of Lecture 4, we arrive at the equation: $$h_\theta(x) = \theta^TX$$ I had some trouble figuring out why this shouldn't be: $$h_\theta(x) = X\theta^T$$ They're obviously not the same since matrix multiplication isn't commutative, and through some brute force calculation I figured out why - viz. the final result [$$h_\theta(x)$$] has to be a single value or a 1x1 matrix which will only result with the $$\theta^TX$$ calculation. However, is there a more intuitive explanation?
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Sonal, For this special case, we are effectively computing a vector dot product which is commutative (A dot B = B dot A). And just so you know, often in the homework, we have to switch the order of operands and/or transpose variables in order to get matrix-matrix and matrix-vector products to be 'compatible'. Finally, and I'm just guessing here, but I think that probably some 'industry/historical notational conventions' are playing a role in the formalism as well;) Hope this helps, Rick

Input.threadtitle: More efficient implementation of normal equations?
Input.posts:
2 related numerical linear algebra questions: #1) According to Wikipedia ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moore–Penrose_pseudoinverse ), a least-squares solution to Ax=b is x=pinv(A)*b. So why use the more complicated x=pinv(A^T*A)*A^T*b? #2) At least in the derivation I've seen, the above equation x=pinv(A^T*A)*A^T*b arises because we need to find the x satisfying (A^T*A)*x = (A^T)*b. But when we solve a matrix equation like Mx = b, it is usually inefficient to invert M and then multiply (O(n^3)), rather than solving the system by Gaussian elimination and back substitution (O(n^2)). Why aren't we doing this? Does pivoting or back substitution not work if M is singular? Even so, isn't the singular case pretty rare when we have real-world data?

You can basically write the equations as provided in the lectures in Octave, and they will satisfy the requirements of the exercise. We aren't doing anything that is performance critical, nor that requires specific tweaks to achieve optimal performance. I'm not saying that your question doesn't have merit, simply that concerns about optimal implementations are really outside the scope of what this course is aiming for. I'm not going to argue for or against your derivation. I'm simply going to suggest that it is not necessary to understanding the concepts of Machine Learning, which is why we are here.
